docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly everyone who worked the commencement speech circuit this spring talked about Sept. 11, whether it was the horror of that morning and its aftermath, or the lessons learned by both the nation's government and its citizens. Tom Ridge, whose cabinet-level position as director of homeland security did not exist at this time last year, was in hot demand, as were writers like Anna Quindlen and Tom Wolfe, who were expected to put the fall's extraordinary events into perspective.

headline.main: Commencement Speeches; Along With Best Wishes, 9/11 Is a Familiar Graduation Theme

docs.abstract: Themes of college commencement speakers across nation noted; excerpts; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding ''What Malpractice Insurance Crisis?'' (Soapbox, May 26): There are some vocal segments of society that dispute the existence of a medical malpractice insurance crisis, claiming that there ''is a campaign being waged in New Jersey against the victims of medical malpractice.''

headline.main: Malpractice Insurance Is Indeed in Crisis

docs.abstract: Mountainside Hospital department head Dr Paul Ehrlich letter on May 26 Soapbox essay disputes contention that there is no malpractice insurance crisis in New Jersey
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Regarding ''What Malpractice Insurance Crisis?'' (Soapbox, May 26): There are some vocal segments of society that dispute the existence of a medical malpractice insurance crisis, claiming that there ''is a campaign being waged in...

docs.lead_paragraph: DOCTOR, heal thyself. Again. With the failure of the state's largest medical liability insurer, doctors in New Jersey -- already facing staggering rate increases from 10 percent to more than 50 percent -- must rescue their troubled malpractice insurance market once more if they ever want to pick up another scalpel.
docs.abstract: Article on New Jersey's troubled medical liability insurance industry, which local doctors are being asked to rescue through financing of several insurance schemes to restore competition and stability; half of state's 24,000 doctors have lost coverage in past year and increasing number plan to move out of state or retire early; in all likelihood, patients will suffer, with higher fees or decline in health care; photos (L)
docs.snippet: DOCTOR, heal thyself. Again.    With the failure of the state's largest medical liability insurer, doctors in New Jersey -- already facing staggering rate increases from 10 percent to more than 50 percent -- must rescue their troubled malpractice...

docs.lead_paragraph: Boston and the Suffolk County Sheriff's Department will pay $10 million to settle a class-action suit brought by women strip-searched at the county jail after being arrested for minor offenses. The settlement was reached nearly a year after a judge in Federal District Court ruled that the automatic searches violated constitutional rights. About 5,400 women searched from 1995 to 1999 are eligible for the payment. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Strip-Search Settlement

docs.abstract: Judge Nancy Gertner rules that Defense Dept violated woman's right to equal protection under Constitution by denying health coverage for abortion of fetus with fatal brain condition; case involves Maureen Britell, wife of captain in Air Force National Guard, who was told in 20th week of pregnancy that her fetus was missing parts of brain and certain to die outside womb (S)
